Award.AwardTitle: iREU in Organic Chemistry in Bangkok, Thailand
Award.AbstractNarration: This international ten-week ThaiREU summer program is designed to give eight students recruited from across the United States an intensive, hands-on research experience in organic chemistry in Bangkok, Thailand: in laboratories at the Chulabhorn Research Institute, Chulalongkorn University and at Mahidol University. Each American undergraduate will be paired with a Thai graduate student. The American ThaiREU students will be housed together at the Chulabhorn Research Institute, and will receive an initial Thai culture, history and language course, which will be supplemented throughout the summer by cultural enrichment outings to important religious and historical locations. Weekly research meetings will be followed by a final Research Colloquium for both American and Thai student participants. In addition, the ThaiREU students will submit written research reports to complete their formal research experience. This 10-week research experience in organic chemistry will provide an intensive, hands-on research experience in a sophisticated, modern Thai laboratory under the personalized mentorship of a Thai faculty member and partnership with a Thai graduate student. Scientifically, the long-range impact of this program will give undergraduates a realistic understanding of the research endeavor, and encourage students to pursue graduate studies. Culturally, this experience will foster cross-cultural communication and understanding, and establish long-term bonds between young American and Thai scientists. This experience will promote the growth of a globally engaged scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
25 American undergraduates recruited nationwide participated in our eight through tenth years of the NSF ThaiREU program (three years for this grant cycle: 2009-2011).  Each year, two worked in organic or bioorganic research labs at Chulalongkorn University, four at the Chulabhorn Research Institute, and two or three at Mahidol University. All ThaiREU students were housed at the Chulabhorn Research Institute. The students arrived in Bangkok in early June, several days before their official ten-week research experience, which ended in mid-August. Director Professor Rebecca Braslau met the students at the airport as they arrived, and provided orientation. On the weekend prior to the official start date, Prof. Braslau and a group of Thai students took the American students to see the a few major sites in Bangkok, such as the Grand Palace and the Temple of the Emerald Buddha. Both Prof. Braslau and co-director Dr. Poonsakdi Ploypradith took the students to near-by shopping to introduce them to grocery stores, and where to get other necessities. For the summer, each American ThaiREU student was paired with a Thai graduate student from the same laboratory. Each student had a unique research project. Both the American students and their Thai partners took part in meetings among all ThaiREU participants: the location of the research meetings rotated between the three participating research institutions.  In addition, they attended the various group meetings of their own laboratories. Early each summer, the students participated in a one-day Thai history and culture and language course. On weekends, the students took part (often with their Thai student partners) in a variety of culture and historical outings, such as visiting the historic ruins of Ayutthaya (the ancient capital of Thailand), a trip to the caves and waterfalls at Erawan National Park, visits to ancient temples, and a variety of other locations. In Bangkok, they attended traditional Thai dance performances and also took a one-day Thai cooking class.

At the end of the 10-week period, both American and Thai students took part in a final Research Symposium at the Chulabhorn Research Institute, where they each gave a 20-minute presentation describing their research accomplishments. Director Prof. Braslau (in California) attended the final Research Symposium “in silico” via Skype. The students submitted final written reports with full experimental details.  To date, their work has resulted in two peer-reviewed publications, with more expected. Over the ten years of the ThaiREU program, twelve publications include work carried out by 14 ThaiREU undergraduate researchers as co-authors.  Ten of the 25 students from this grant cycle presented their research results from their ThaiREU summer experience at professional meetings upon returning to the USA.

Each American summer student received a summer stipend in addition to housing in Bangkok, round-trip airfare from their homes in the USA to Thailand, and overseas emergency medical insurance. Of the 25 participants in this 3-year grant cycle, 12 participants were women (including one underrepresented minority), and 13 were men (including 3 underrepresented minorities). 

Following participation in the ThaiREU program, Director Braslau keeps track of the careers paths of the former participants. Of the 25 participants from this grant cycle, 17 have continued pursuing science studies at the graduate level, two are working in National Research Laboratories, one has gone to medical school, one became a professional science writer, one is taking time off before graduate school, and three are working in industry.
